title: APRA will not appeal IOOF decision
text:
The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority will not appeal a Federal Court decision that cleared wealth business IOOF and five of its executives and directors of misconduct.

APRA failed to have five IOOF directors and executives, including former managing director Chris Kelaher, disqualified. AFR

APRA deputy chairman Helen Rowell said the regulator decided it was necessary to take court action after concerns about conflicts and trustee duties were not adequately dealt with by IOOF over several years.

Although the case was dismissed, the judgment nevertheless raised some issues of wider importance for APRA in its supervision of superannuation trustees, she said.

"APRA is considering any further action that may need to be taken in relation to these, such as revising its prudential standards or seeking legislative amendments, to ensure that member interests are protected to the maximum extent possible," a statement from the regulator says.

"APRA notes that, notwithstanding the decision not to appeal the judgment, additional licence conditions that APRA imposed on IOOF in December remain in force and APRA’s strengthened supervision focus on ensuring that IOOF implements the changes needed to comply with these conditions continues."
description: The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority will not appeal a Federal Court decision that cleared IOOF and five of its executives and directors of misconduct but is considering changes to its standards and the law.
